posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
A very useful feature here on discourse is the ability to select several words of a post and press ‚Äúquote‚Äù. It allows others to very spesifically reply to a certain statement.

I feel it would not be as important in a messaging app as it would be on a discussion form, as messages are usually short and segmented already, but sometimes maybe it would help yo reply to a spesific thing a chat partner wrote. Maybe we could add a similar select and quote function in Signal.

Just an idea, not really sure about it yet. It would mean ‚Äòmore power to Signal users‚Äô. When I try to think of how it might disrupt a messaging app‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt think it would be very disruptive, as long as we can still fast reply to whole messages as well.

link_counts.title: Partially copy text from Signal messages
Partial Reply - great for long messages
Messages with media/file: text below or above option
Disappearing Messages are retained (i.e. leak) through quoted-reply previews

posts.cooked:
Meteor0id:

sometimes maybe it would help yo reply to a spesific thing a chat partner wrote

Yes. Especially if they write a lot of stuff. (For some reason ALL my contacts wanted text-select‚Ä¶ hmmm.)

  • Alice 1:11pm == hey bob you want to eat lunch at 6pm in the usual place?

  •               Alice 1:11pm wrote: ‚Äú‚Ä¶lunch‚Ä¶‚Äù
  • Alice 1:22pm == arrgh what I meant was supper‚Ä¶ wish I had RequestEdit ;-)

Also, for that matter, sometimes helpful to quoted-reply-to-your-own-message, if you sent a mistake in what you wrote. Not everybody groks s/lunch/supper/

p.s. Discussed earlier, under ‚Äú#6B‚Äù feature-request

Contacts refuse to use Signal because it lacks many things

I want to be able to swipeRight to select some text‚Ä¶

link_counts.title: Allow Unlimited Text Length For Signal Encrypted Messages

posts.cooked:
Telegram has this now:

Telegram ‚Äì 28 Oct 23

Replies 2.0, Adjustable Link Previews, Name Colors and More

Today's update lets you quote specific parts of messages when replying, send your replies to other chats, add quote formatting to any text, configure link previews, choose a color for your account, and much more.

link_counts.title: Replies 2.0, Adjustable Link Previews, Name Colors and More

posts.cooked:
Reply only on parts of a message. This would be very useful, if someone wrote a very long message and you only want to refer to one or two sentences - or even only one or a few words.
If you click on the quote the part of the message that was quoted would appear in another color.

I suggested this also for the Telegram messenger a while ago, this is why the mockup shows the Telegram UI‚Ä¶
For Signal the feature to select single words of a message had to be implemented first to make partial replies work‚Ä¶

TelegramPartialReply-Mockup640√ó1136 101 KB

TelegramPartialReply-Mockup2640√ó1136 172 KB

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: This is a cool feature and is useful for interacting with longer messages, but I feel like a multi quote feature would be more useful, getting into mark-up text. I‚Äôd prefer Signal implement a reply privately feature first.

Yes, I agree. Reply privately for groups is also important. I also thought about a multi quote feature, but I think this could get very fast very messy, especially on small screens like phones. And the workaround to type for every answer a seperate message is not so bad and reasonable, I think‚Ä¶
In the meantime this feature was added to Telegram. In this blog post the feature is demonstrated

link_counts.title: Replies 2.0, Adjustable Link Previews, Name Colors and More

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked: I wonder if the telegram and whatsapp design teams read these signal communityvforum feature requests more thoroughly than the Signal design team does.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: or maybe it‚Äôs just that it‚Äôs a relatively obvious feature request and since they have more money and less security to care about they can just go ahead and do it?

Selecting parts of a message is coming to WhatsApp:

WABetaInfo ‚Äì 2 Jun 25

WhatsApp beta for Android 2.25.18.3: what's new? | WABetaInfo

Discover the WhatsApp beta for Android 2.25.18.3 update: WhatsApp is working on a new feature to select and copy parts of a chat message!

Estimated reading time: 4 minutes

WABetaInfo ‚Äì 1 Jun 25

WhatsApp for iOS 25.16.81: what's new? | WABetaInfo

Discover the WhatsApp for iOS 25.16.81 update on the App Store: WhatsApp is rolling out a feature to select and copy parts of a chat message!

Estimated reading time: 4 minutes

On the screenshot for Android, options to reply to, edit, forward, copy, etc. parts of a message are available. On the screenshot for iOS, these options are not yet included.

link_counts.title: WhatsApp beta for Android 2.25.18.3: what's new? | WABetaInfo
WhatsApp for iOS 25.16.81: what's new? | WABetaInfo

link_counts.title: iOS 26 Finally Fixes This Annoying Messages Problem - MacRumors

posts.cooked:
That‚Äôs the no-1-feature I miss most on Signal. It‚Äôs very handy in other messengers and Signal should get this feature too. Because it makes much clearer to what you reply if you reply to a longer message.

My suggestion how to do it in the GUI:
when you quote a message there‚Äôs only a small preview of te first words. But if you tap-and-hold it or move your finger above it (like when you try to select text) it should expand and allow to select the text you‚Äôre replying to.

FinnTimm:

My suggestion how to do it in the GUI:
when you quote a message there‚Äôs only a small preview of te first words. But if you tap-and-hold it or move your finger above it (like when you try to select text) it should expand and allow to select the text you‚Äôre replying to.

Why tap and hold or tap and move? A simple tap (without holding or moving) would be sufficient, because it isn‚Äôt used for anything else. And it would improve the discoverability of the feature.

CarstenW:

Why tap and hold or tap and move? A simple tap (without holding or moving) would be sufficient, because it isn‚Äôt used for anything else. And it would improve the discoverability of the feature.

I agree. That would be better. There‚Äôs no need to make it more complicated.
